Author: jl777c#5810
Content:
from the chainlink whitepaper:
"Detecting outlying or incorrect values is a problem that is specific to each type
of data feed and application. For instance, detecting and rejecting outlying answers
before averaging may be necessary for numeric data but not boolean. For this reason,
there will not be a specific aggregating contract, but a configurable contract address
which is specified by the purchaser. ChainLink will include a standard set of aggregating contracts, but customized contracts may also be specified, provided they
conform to the standard calculation interface."

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: A lawyer saying jl777c's code is "stupid", well this is new

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it sure sounds like data aggregation. maybe this can be mitigated to some degree.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: also the incentive for miners to mine proper prices is the incentive to mine blocks. all prices are part of the coinbase, without valid prices, no new blockl

Author: CryptoNinjaa#5350
Content: https://twitter.com/LtColLinkarski/status/1118628353475354624

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it says right there "off-chain aggregation"

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: He actually called our trustless oracles "stupid" three times in one twitter thread, this lawyer really like us

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: they do some fancy math to prevent freeloading

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but onchain or offchain aggregation, is still aggregation

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: I have a math degree, I can spot "fake math" and "lying with statistics" a mile away. @jl777c I am happy to give a math analysis of any algorithm you want me to look at

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: aggregating a bunch of prices from random sources is as silly as VBK trusting notarizations by random miners

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: my algo doesnt need math to prove itself as it is common sense. all nodes validate all prices, so each node becomes part of the decentralized trustless oracle

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: there is no master node telling the others what the value is

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: there is no aggregating of trusted sources

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: all nodes validate, like decentralization

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: aggregating "trusted sources" is open to Sybil attacks, right?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if the trust is based on reputation, then you are limited by the value of the reputation. nothing prevents them from lying other than the loss of reputation

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: I am unclear on how everybody defines trusted/trustless, I read the convo for days with Zack/jl777+others, but it was a lot

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if you trust the source, then sybil attacks are not possible without infiltration, but it becomes a trusted oracle

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if you rely on a node to be honest, you are trusting that node

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if every node validates, it is trustless

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: sounds like Twitter is just arguing over the definition of words again, which LAWYERS love, it's what they are paid to do. Their existence is governed by them getting judges to agree to their definitions of words

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: since it doesnt matter what any other node says, if the data is invalid, each node will see that for itself

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is possible to mitigate the problems caused by data aggregation, by stake weighting, reputation, feedback, secondary reward coin, etc.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but that requires a very complex structure and can you really be sure it is really immune from attacks?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i did the trustless oracle in a week, a few bug fixes over the next few weeks, it is very small amount of code. cant be too complex

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: :troll_king:

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: does chainlink say that there is no exploit possible? I think the data can be messed with, but then it can be detected and the culprits punished. while this is good for the long term, it does mean that invalid data can be oraclized

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so it is a bad data detection system? but who detects the bad data if the bad data got oraclized? how it is undone and fixed? is the blockchain rolled back?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: in a complex system, all sorts of complex things can happen, especially at the edge cases

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i do agree that chainlink has some clever things to prevent leeching (where one node copies another nodes data, so doesnt do much work), but that isnt the main problem
